lessons.insight: The middle term in a syllogism appears in both premises but never in the conclusion.
lessons.example: All humans are mortal. Socrates is human. Therefore Socrates is mortal. 'Human' is the middle term.

lessons.insight: Ethos establishes credibility, Pathos appeals to emotion, Logos uses logic. Master all three.
lessons.example: A doctor (ethos) describing patient suffering (pathos) with statistics (logos).

lessons.insight: The method of loci works because spatial memory is stronger than abstract memory.
lessons.example: Remember a shopping list by placing items in rooms of your house.

lessons.insight: Ad hominem attacks the person, not the argument. Always address the claim, not the claimant.
lessons.example: Rejecting an idea because 'you're not qualified' is ad hominem.

lessons.insight: Virtue ethics focuses on character, not rules. What would a virtuous person do?
lessons.example: Instead of 'Is this allowed?', ask 'Is this the right thing to do?'

lessons.insight: Socratic questioning exposes assumptions. Ask 'Why?' five times to reach truth.
lessons.example: Why do you believe that? What evidence supports it? What would change your mind?
